awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Midwest Arithmetic Geometry and Number Theory Series
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports participation in a series of three weekend conferences in arithmetic geometry and number theory over three years (tentatively scheduled at the University of Illinois at Chicago, November 7-8, 2020; the University of Michigan, October 9-10, 2021; and the Ohio State University, October 22-23, 2022). This series, titled "Midwest Arithmetic Geometry and Number Theory Series (MAGNTS)" aims to bring together the researchers of the Midwest universities at various career stages. More information about the 2019 conference can be found at magnts.org.

Each conference will have several components. Two mini-courses (approximately three hours each) by established researchers in number theory or arithmetic geometry will be followed by two research presentations (one hour each) by mid-career researchers in areas related to the mini-courses. The participants will get a chance to present their own research during a poster session, and there will be a career panel featuring people from various career paths, including academia, industry, and government positions. Through this setup, the conferences aim to expose the participants to cutting-edge research areas, as well as to provide an opportunity to explore various career options while networking with others of similar mathematical backgrounds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
MAGNTS (Midwest Arithmetic Geometry and Number Theory Series) is an annual series of weekend conferences in arithmetic geometry and number theory. This series aim to bring together the researchers from Midwest universities in these areas at various career stages. More information about the series can be found at magnts.org.

Each MAGNTS conference has several components. There are two mini-courses (approximately three hours each) by established researchers in number theory or arithmetic geometry; in turn, these are followed by two research presentations (one hour each) by mid-career researchers in areas related to the mini-courses. Participants are also given a chance to present their own research during a poster session, and there is a career panel featuring people from various career paths, including academia, industry, and government positions. The intellectual merit stems from the exchange of mathematical ideas, where the conference exposes participants to cutting-edge research areas. The broader impacts include the opportunities provided to participants to explore various career options while networking with others of similar mathematical backgrounds. Every effort is made to ensure a diverse group of speakers and attendees.

This grant overlapped with the pandemic period, which delayed the series from its original dates. In the interim period, an online "Mini-MAGNTS" ran as a one day online mini-syposium on August 11, 2021 at no cost. The online symposium was specifically tailored towards professional development activities for graduate students in arithmetic geometry and algebraic geometry likely to soon be finishing their degrees.

The primary instance of MAGNTS funded by this grant was held at UIC on October 22 & 23, 2022, with around 100 attendees in total. The majority of the attendees were peridoctoral researchers. Full details on the event can be found here

https://www.magnts.org/2022

with plenary lecture series by Linquan Ma (Purdue) on "Perfectoid algebras and singularities in mixed characteristic" and another by Tim Browning (IST Austria) on "Rational points on random varieties: locally and globally". Additional lectures by Stephanie Chan (Michigan) on "Integral points in families of elliptic curves" and Jakub Witaszek (Princeton) on "Quasi-F-splittings" were also given. 15 graduate and postdoctoral participants also presented posters as well. Some funds were also used to support the subsequent iteration of MAGNTS held at the University of Michigan on October 7 & 8, 2023.
